title: 115_s3166
content: The Act is titled the "United States Army Rangers Veterans of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act." It defines a "United States Army Rangers Veteran of World War II" as an individual who served honorably in an active duty status in the Armed Forces between June 19, 1942, and September 2, 1945, and was assigned to a Ranger Battalion of the Army during that period. During World War II, the Army formed 6 Ranger Battalions and 1 provisional battalion, all consisting of volunteers. The concept of Ranger units was inspired by British commando units and the US military tradition of using light infantry for scouting and raiding operations. The Ranger Battalions included the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd Infantry Battalions activated at different locations and dates. During World War II, the Army formed 6 Ranger Battalions and 1 provisional battalion, all consisting of volunteers. The 4th Ranger Infantry Battalion was activated on May 29, 1943, in North Africa, and consolidated on July 21, 1943. The 5th Ranger Infantry Battalion was activated on September 1, 1943, at Camp Forrest, Tennessee. The 6th Ranger Infantry Battalion was originally activated on January 20. The Army formed 6 Ranger Battalions and 1 provisional battalion during World War II, all consisting of volunteers. The first combat operations of Army Rangers occurred on August 19, 1942, during a raid on Dieppe. During the North African campaign, the 1st Ranger Battalion led by Major William O. Darby achieved success in difficult battles, leading to the formation of 2 additional Ranger Battalions. The Battalion was awarded battle honors for actions in Tunisia, including capturing enemy positions and defending against the German Afrika Korps. The 29th provisional Ranger Battalion, formed from volunteers of the 29th Infantry Division, demonstrated courage in raids in Norway and France. After a successful raid on a German radar site, the Battalion was disbanded to make way for new Ranger units. During 1943, the 1st, 3d, and 4th Ranger Battalions were active in Sicily and Italy. The 1st and 4th Rangers secured landing beaches in Sicily, while the 3d Battalion silenced gun positions in Licata. In Italy, the 1st and 4th Rangers seized high ground at Maori despite being outnumbered by enemy forces. After the invasion of Italy, Rangers continued to be used in night attacks to seize key terrain ahead of advancing Allied forces. At the Anzio beachhead, the majority of the 1st, 3d, and 4th Ranger Battalions sustained heavy casualties after being cut off behind German lines. Only 6 Rangers out of more than 767 men returned to friendly lines after a failed mission to infiltrate German positions. The 4th Battalion, along with two other battalions, suffered heavy casualties and were inactivated. The 2nd and 5th Ranger Battalions were formed for operations in Western Europe, engaging in combat on D-Day at Pointe du Hoc. Rangers in the 2nd Battalion, led by Lieutenant Colonel James E. Rudder, overcame obstacles to secure the cliffs against German forces. During June, July, and August of 1944, the 2d and 5th Ranger Battalions were engaged in close-range fighting in hedgerows and villages in Brest. In Western Germany, they attacked in darkness to secure vital positions for the main Army attacks. The 5th Ranger Battalion was commended for outstanding performance during the final drive into Germany in late February and early March 1945. The 6th Ranger Battalion earned battle honors for seizing high ground in German lines, resulting in heavy casualties during 5 days of fighting. Their actions allowed the main Army attack to overcome German defenses, capture Trier, and reach the Rhine River. In the Pacific, the Battalion rescued over 500 Allied prisoners from the Cabanatuan POW camp in the Philippines in 1945. The 1st Ranger Infantry Battalion, led by Lieutenant Colonel Henry A. Mucci, demonstrated heroism by infiltrating Japanese-held territory to rescue prisoners of war at the Cabanatuan camp in the Philippines. They successfully killed all Japanese sentries, returned to American lines with minimal casualties, and participated in various campaigns. The 2d Ranger Infantry Battalion participated in campaigns in Normandy, Northern France, Rhineland, Ardennes-Alsace, and Central Europe. They received the Presidential Unit Citation with streamers embroidered with "EL GUETTAR" and "SALERNO" for their contributions. The 3d Ranger Infantry Battalion participated in campaigns in Sicily, Naples-Foggia, Anzio, and Rome-Arno. They received the Presidential Unit Citation with a streamer embroidered with "SALERNO" for their contributions. The 4th Ranger Infantry Battalion participated in campaigns in Sicily, Naples-Foggia, Anzio, and Rome-Arno. They received the Presidential Unit Citation with a streamer embroidered with "SALERNO". The 5th Ranger Infantry Battalion participated in campaigns in Normandy, Northern France, Rhineland, Ardennes-Alsace, and Central Europe. The 6th Ranger Infantry Battalion participated in campaigns in New Guinea, Leyte (with arrowhead), and Luzon. They received the Presidential Unit Citation (Army) for their contributions. The United States Army Rangers Veterans of World War II received the Presidential Unit Citation (Army) and the Philippine Presidential Unit Citation for their bravery and sacrifice in combat, contributing greatly to the military success of the United States and its allies. The Congressional Gold Medal is awarded to the United States Army Rangers Veterans of World War II for their bravery and sacrifice in combat. The President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives will arrange for the award of a single gold medal to the United States Army Rangers Veterans of World War II. The gold medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary with suitable emblems. After the award, the gold medal will be given to the Smithsonian Institution for display and research. The Smithsonian Institution will make the gold medal received for the United States Army Rangers Veterans of World War II available for display elsewhere, particularly at locations associated with World War II. The Secretary may also strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze to cover costs. The gold medal struck under section 4 is a national medal for the purposes of title 31, United States Code, and all medals struck under section 4 are considered numismatic items.
